sections.title: Book I: Gratitude and Role Models
sections.content: From my grandfather Verus I learned good morals and the government of my temper. From the reputation and remembrance of my father, modesty and a manly character. From my mother, piety and beneficence, and abstinence, not only from evil deeds, but even from evil thoughts; and further, simplicity in my way of living, far removed from the habits of the rich. From my great-grandfather, not to have frequented public schools, and to have had good teachers at home, and to know that on such things a man should spend liberally.

sections.title: Book I: Legacy and Duty
sections.content: From Rusticus I received the impression that my character required improvement and discipline; and from him I learned not to be led astray to sophistic emulation, nor to writing on speculative matters, nor to delivering little hortatory orations, nor to showing myself off as a man of letters or a philanthropist or a busybody. I learned to abstain from rhetoric, poetry, and fine writing; and not to walk about in the house in my outdoor dress, nor to do other things of the kind; nor to write letters in a style that seeks to please, like the letters of Rusticus.

sections.title: Book II: Morning Practice
sections.content: Begin the morning by saying to thyself, I shall meet with the busybody, the ungrateful, arrogant, deceitful, envious, unsocial. All these things happen to them by reason of their ignorance of what is good and evil. But I who have seen the nature of the good that it is beautiful, and of the bad that it is ugly, and the nature of him who does wrong, that it is akin to me, not only of the same blood or seed, but that it participates in the same intelligence and the same portion of the divinity, I can neither be injured by any of them, for no one can fix on me what is ugly, nor can I be angry with my kinsman, nor hate him.

sections.title: Book II: The Soul's Nature
sections.content: Everything that happens is either endurable or not. If it is endurable, then endure it. Stop complaining. If it is unendurable, then stop complaining. Your destruction will mean its end as well. But remember, you can endure anything your mind can make endurable, by treating it as in your interest to do so. In your interest, or in your nature. If it is in your interest to treat something as easy, treat it as easy. If as profitable, treat it as profitable. If as duty, treat it as duty. And if you complain about a thing, you add to its harm.

sections.title: Book III: Death and Perspective
sections.content: Alexander the Great and his mule driver both died and the same thing happened to both. They were absorbed alike into the generative principle of the universe. Or they were alike distributed into atoms. Consider how many times a day your thoughts dwell on death, and yet you do not reflect that when you have died, you will no longer be troubled by any such thoughts. Is not this strange? Or do you not think it strange that a man should live as if he were never going to die, and yet complain when death comes slowly?

sections.title: Book III: Inner Citadel
sections.content: The mind is its own place, and in itself can make a heaven of hell, a hell of heaven. If you have a wound, you can retreat to your own mind and be at peace. If you are troubled, you can find refuge in your ruling faculty. For the mind, when it is not itself disturbed, is not disturbed by anything external. What then can disturb the mind? The answer is: opinions about things. Take away these opinions, and peace remains. And who can take away opinions? Only the mind itself, by refusing to accept them.

sections.title: Book IV: Inner Retreat
sections.content: The happiness of your life depends upon the quality of your thoughts. Therefore, guard accordingly, and take care that you entertain no notions unsuitable to virtue and reasonable nature. Men seek retreats for themselves, houses in the country, sea-shores, and mountains; and thou too art wont to desire such things very much. But this is altogether a mark of the most common sort of men, for it is in thy power whenever thou shalt choose to retire into thyself. For nowhere either with more quiet or more freedom from trouble does a man retire than into his own soul.

sections.title: Book IV: Nature's Design
sections.content: Everything is interwoven, and the web is holy; there is probably not one thread that is isolated or alone. For all things are interdependent, and they combine to form the same universe. For there is one universe made up of all things, and one god who pervades all things, and one substance, and one law, one common reason in all intelligent animals, and one truth. If this is so, then there is also one perfection for all who are of the same stock and participate in the same reason.

sections.title: Book V: Providence and Acceptance
sections.content: Whatever happens to you has been waiting to happen since the beginning of time. The twining strands of fate weave both good and ill into the same cloth. The one is inseparable from the other. If you accept this, you will accept whatever happens with equanimity. For what is the difference between accepting it now or later? The events are the same. Only your attitude toward them changes. Accept what nature sends you. In the long run, it makes no difference whether you accept it or not. But in the short run, acceptance brings peace.

sections.title: Book V: The Present Moment
sections.content: Do not disturb thyself by thinking of the whole of thy life. Let not thy thoughts at once embrace all the various troubles that thou mayest expect to befall thee: but on every occasion ask thyself, What is there in this that is intolerable and past bearing? For thou wilt be ashamed to confess. In the next place, remember that neither the future nor the past pains thee, but only the present. But this is reduced to a very little, if thou only circumscribest it, and chidest thy mind, if it is unable to hold out against even this.

sections.title: Book VI: Self-Knowledge
sections.content: The best way of avenging thyself is not to become like the wrong doer. The best way of avenging thyself is to become unlike him. The best way of avenging thyself is to forgive him. The best way of avenging thyself is to love him. For hatred never ceases by hatred, but by love alone is healed. This is an ancient and eternal law. The happiness of thy life depends upon the quality of thy thoughts: therefore, guard accordingly, and take care that thou entertain no notions unsuitable to virtue and reasonable nature.

sections.title: Book VI: True Self
sections.content: Look within. Within is the fountain of good, and it will ever bubble up, if thou wilt ever dig. The soul must be made impervious to all external influences. It must be like a fortress, whose garrison is reason. For the soul that is disciplined and purified is a fortress that cannot be taken. The soul that is in harmony with reason is a fortress that cannot be shaken. The soul that is in harmony with nature is a fortress that cannot be conquered.

sections.title: Book VII: Impermanence
sections.content: How ridiculous and how strange to be surprised at anything which happens in life! If a potter makes a vessel and it breaks in the kiln or oven, is he surprised? No. But if a man breaks, we say, 'Alas, what has happened?' Learn then not to be surprised at the breakage of a vessel, nor at the death of a man. For as the vessel is broken, so must a man die. And what is more, the wife of a potter or the child of a baker must also die. For everything that exists is subject to change, and nothing remains the same.

sections.title: Book VII: Eternity and Perspective
sections.content: Consider the whole universe as one living being, having one substance and one soul; and observe how all things have reference to one perception, the perception of this one living being; and how all things act with one movement; and how all things are the cooperating causes of all things that exist; observe too the continuous spinning of the thread and the structure of the web. Thou art a part of this great being, and a part of thee is separated; but thou hast a share in the government of the whole, and thou knowest it.

sections.title: Book VIII: Social Duty
sections.content: Constantly regard the universe as one living being, having one substance and one soul; and observe how all things trace back to one perception, the perception of this one living being; and how all things act with one movement; and how all things are the cooperating causes of all things which exist. Observe too the continuous spinning of the thread and the contexture of the web. Man is a part of this great being, and has his share in the government of the whole; but he is also separated from it, and knows what he does.

sections.title: Book IX: Human Nature
sections.content: It is in our power to have no opinion about a thing, and not to be disturbed in our soul; for things themselves have no natural power to form our judgments. Practice then from the start to say to every harsh appearance, 'Thou art but an appearance, and not absolutely the thing thou appearest to be.' And then examine it by those rules which thou hast, and first, and chiefly, by this: whether it concerns the things which are in our power, or things which are not in our power; and, if it concerns anything not in our power, be prepared to say that it is nothing to thee.

sections.title: Book X: Morning Renewal
sections.content: My soul, why dost thou not use thy freedom? For all that thou hast is sufficient for thee. Thou hast the power to will and not to will, and to choose and to refuse. Why then dost thou not use this power? If thou dost not use it, thou art enslaved. But if thou dost use it, thou art free. Remember that thou hast the power to withdraw thyself from many things, and to have need of few things. For thou hast the power to live as a philosopher, if thou dost not live as one, thou art not worthy of the name.

sections.title: Book XI: Divine Reason
sections.content: Everything that happens is in accordance with the nature of the universe. Nothing happens contrary to nature. If thou dost not see this, thou dost not see that all things happen for the best. For if thou dost see it, thou wilt be content with everything that happens. But if thou dost not see it, thou wilt be discontented with everything. Remember that the universe is one living being, having one substance and one soul. And remember that thou art a part of this great being, and hast thy share in the government of the whole.

sections.title: Book XII: Evening Reflection
sections.content: When thou art offended at any man's fault, immediately turn to thyself and reflect in what manner thou dost err thyself. For example, if thou art offended because a man is ungrateful, turn thy thoughts to thyself, and consider whether thou thyself hast not been ungrateful to others. If thou art offended because a man is faithless, consider whether thou thyself hast not been faithless. For by attending to this, thou wilt forget thy anger, and wilt be less prone to it in the future. Remember that to be offended is to be angry with thyself for not having foreseen the fault.
